Award.AwardTitle: Future Urban STEM Educator Capacity Building Project

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Future Urban STEM Educator (FUSE) is a Capacity Building Project at Davenport University (DU). FUSE will institute plans to increase the number of STEM students who pursue and become prepared for teaching urban youth. The main goal of the FUSE project is to create a STEM educator pipeline through DU's Certificate in Urban Education program. The project aims to produce a plan for increasing the enrollment and diversity of students pursuing STEM teaching careers within DU's computer science and biological laboratory science bachelor's degree programs. FUSE will accomplish this objective by (1) establishing new dual enrollment pathways for high school and community college students to enter DU's computer science and biological laboratory science degree programs on an accelerated schedule and at reduced cost; (2) creating future teacher clubs at diverse high schools that expand opportunities for high school students to participate in teaching experiences and develop an early interest in a STEM education career; (3) creating service-learning opportunities within the computer science and biological laboratory science programs that provide teaching experiences; and (4) developing a new education course and capstone internship experience to prepare computer science and biological laboratory science majors to enter STEM education and prepare for the Michigan Test for Teacher Certification.

DU's College of Urban Education will collaborate with existing and new school partnerships (Hope Academy, Eaton Regional Education Service Agency, and Grand Rapids Community College). These partnerships will support the establishment of middle college and dual enrollment programs with a curricular focus on computer science and biological laboratory science. Additionally, service learning programming will be developed in partnership with the Expanded Learning Opportunities (ELO) network. ELO provides afterschool and summer programs for 67% of African-American children and 41% of Latino children within the project's geographic area. DU has campuses throughout Michigan's urban areas where shortages of STEM educators exist. FUSE will support the ability of the College of Urban Education to establish the partnerships and infrastructure necessary to implement a new STEM education pathway throughout the state. Students will benefit from the new curricular elements developed through the FUSE project, including a foundational teacher education course, education-based service learning, and a capstone internship experience in education. FUSE responds to the national call for change in STEM teacher preparation as well as Michigan's need for effective teachers to serve students in urban schools. Through the FUSE Capacity Building project, the College of Urban Education will have the potential to develop STEM teachers who can foster equity, creativity, and opportunity for urban youth.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Davenport University established the Future Urban STEM Educator (FUSE) Capacity Building Program, in partnership with Hope Academy of West Michigan, Grand Rapids Public Schools, Grand Rapids Urban League, and the Detroit Area Pre-College Engineering Program (DAPCEP). FUSE created new relationships between Davenport's College of Urban Education (CUE), College of Technology, and College of Arts and Sciences, developed new pathways into STEM education from high schools, and introduced new STEM education components to the undergraduate curriculum. Two undergraduate STEM majors were included: computer science (CS) and biological laboratory science (BLS).

The objectives of this project were to (1) establish dual enrollment pathways for high school students to enter Davenport's CS and BLS degree programs; (2) expand opportunities for high school students from urban school districts to participate in teaching experiences and develop an interest in STEM education careers; (3) create service-learning opportunities within the CS and BLS programs to provide teaching experiences that inspire undergraduate students to pursue STEM education; and (4) develop new curricular resources and materials to prepare CS and BLS undergraduates to enter STEM education and prepare for the state teacher certification test.

Two partnerships were established to provide dual enrollment pathways to enter Davenport's CS and BLS degree programs. These programs scheduled to begin Fall of 2021, will provide high school students pathways into Davenport's STEM discipline-centered degree programs at junior status having completed 60 credits or having earned an associate degree.

The PI and co-PIs researched activities  and created materials for the following FUSE afterschool modules: Water Quality (Environmental Science/ Social Justice focused); Urban STEAM Farming (Biology focused); Surface Area/Volume (Biology/Math focused); Sound (Physics focused); Robotics (Technology focused); Polymers (Chemistry focused); Hot Wheels (Physics/Math focused); and Chemical Reactions (Chemistry focused). The modules were then compiled into a student manual and a teacher manual for distribution to various afterschool sites. Each module has three components, a STEM activity, a culturally relevant activity, and arts- focused activity (music, visual arts, and literacy/writing)

Afterschool FUSE clubs were established at four sites. Three sites ran clubs from Fall 2019-Spring 2020 but were stopped early due to the pandemic. The fourth site planned to run a pilot version of the club, and then fully institute the club Fall 2020; however, their club was cancelled due to COVID-19. These clubs expanded opportunities for high school students to participate in teaching experiences with middle schoolers and develop an interest in STEM education careers.

In collaboration with the Michigan Education Corps, Davenport high school summer camps (CSI Davenport Camp, Bytes Computer Camp, and Numb3rs Math Camp), and Davenport middle school STEM Day initiatives, several service-learning opportunities within the CS and BLS programs were established to provide teaching experiences that inspire undergraduates to pursue the Certificate in Urban Education, Davenport University's post-baccalaureate teacher certification program. Upon completion of this graduate certificate program, students completing 18 additional credits can earn a Master of Education in Urban Education.

We developed curricular resources and materials to prepare CS and BLS undergraduate students for entry into STEM education through new education methods courses for undergraduates focused on culturally responsive teaching practices. Additionally, we developed modules to prepare students for the Michigan Test for Teacher Certification (MTTC  passage  is required to earn an interim teaching certificate which is an entry level teaching certification qualifying candidates to teach in Michigan)  We developed a test-taking strategies workshop for students to complete prior to taking the MTTC. For each MTTC discipline test, we developed a repository of resources, including study guides and sample questions, all aligned to the State of Michigan competencies, which are required to successfully pass the state licensure exam.

We also developed an undergraduate degree completion program for paraprofessionals and long-term substitute teachers that want to pursue teacher certification through our post-baccalaureate program.  These candidates are able to transfer in previously earned college credits and complete their degree through Davenport's Bachelor of Applied Science in Integrated Sciences program.  Specialized curriculum pathways were developed to form Urban Education tracks in Secondary Integrated Science, Mathematics, and Elementary Integrated Science. Students earn their degree and gain all the content knowledge required to become STEM educators by completing their bachelor's degree through one of these curriculum tracks.  Upon completion of their bachelor's degree, they proceed to receive the necessary training to be highly effective urban educators through our Certificate in Urban Education post baccalaureate teacher certification program.

The work accomplished through this capacity building project has estsblished a model for building pathways that engage non-traditional students to pursue careers in STEM education through structured partnerships with school districts, specific secondary schools, community organizations and community colleges. Widespread replication of this model would facilitate recruitment from urban settings, students of color, low-income students, first generation college students, paraprofessionals and long-term substitutes desiring to pursue  STEM education careers across the country.
